description.narrative: Fairtrade Finland is a non-profit civic movement with a vision to secure sustainable livelihoods for vulnerablefarmers and agricultural workers. The programme complements certification in the areas where certification isnot enough: climate change child lab our and forced labour deforestation unfair trading practices degradationof biodiversity and discrimination against persons with disabilities youth and other genders.We apply Kate Raworth?s Doughnut Economics Model as the theoretical framework for the progr amme. TheDoughnut presents the boundaries for sustainable life on earth based on a social foundation and ecologicalceiling between which is the space where socially economically and ecologically sustainable life happens. Theprogramme ToC includes the three sustainability areas and its development objective is to enable therightsholders to reach sustainable livelihoods without breaking the ecological ceiling.The programme is carbon-negative. Its cross-cutting objectives are gender equality youth and vulnerab legroups especially persons with disabilities. The programme strengthens the capacities of the producers?organisations and develops the operational environment for civic organisations and trade unions. We aim forsystemic change covering all actors in the v alue chain extending advocacy work at every level.Communications play a significant role in the change by activating Finns. Programme effectiveness is ensuredby a holistic results-based and human-rights based approach local ownership and efficiency. Thesus tainability of the results derives from Fairtrade standards participatory planning low aid dependencysustainable exit strategies robust risk management and a thorough MEL system. The programme implementsinnovative pilots like fair carbon credits upcycling of side streams and inclusive HREDD dialogues.The focus is on LDCs and fragile countries especially in Africa. The main partners are the producer networksrepresenting farmers and agricultural workers. Other partners include corporates CSOs towns and other actorsparticipating in the implementation. The programme targets 139000 rightsholders of whom 61% are women.
